commit_message:
Validation to detect if undercloud disks use 512e

If they do use Advanced Format, the overcloud images may fail to upload
to Glance.

Change-Id: I95ad7d2a0368418620d633d0a8b556999b3db34b
Co-Authored-By: Tomas Sedovic <tsedovic@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 2e1a198c6b5b39cc8dddcc7097696e9e0b22b00e)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations refs/changes/63/392863/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # Copyright 2016 Red Hat, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from os import path from ansible.module_utils.basic import * # noqa def read_int(module, file_path): '''Read a file and convert its value to int. Raise ansible failure otherwise. ''' try: with open(file_path) as f: file_contents = f.read() return int(file_contents) except IOError: module.fail_json(msg="Cannot open '%s'" % file_path) except ValueError: module.fail_json(msg="The '%s' file doesn't contain an integer value" % file_path) def main(): module = AnsibleModule(argument_spec=dict( drive=dict(required=True, type='str') )) drive = module.params.get('drive') queue_path = path.join('/sys/class/block', drive, 'queue') physical_block_size_path = path.join(queue_path, 'physical_block_size') logical_block_size_path = path.join(queue_path, 'logical_block_size') physical_block_size = read_int(module, physical_block_size_path) logical_block_size = read_int(module, logical_block_size_path) if physical_block_size == logical_block_size: module.exit_json( changed=False, msg="The disk %s probably doesn't use Advance Format." % drive, ) else: module.exit_json( # NOTE(shadower): we're marking this as `changed`, to make it # visually stand out when running via Ansible directly instead of # using the API. # # The API & UI is planned to look for the `warnings` field and # display it differently. changed=True, warnings=["Physical and logical block sizes of drive %s differ " "(%s vs. %s). This can mean the disk uses Advance " "Format." % (drive, physical_block_size, logical_block_size)], ) if __name__ == '__main__': main()

Validate haproxy configuration values

Unit testing will happen in a separate commit, see:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1594785

Change-Id: I531bb19f5e1a12f3bb88e93816e1047a5bd05055
Co-Authored-By: Martin Andr <m.andre@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 29de0e23d86f0994e08fd25ab2396c6a04fb8cfb)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations refs/changes/61/392861/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import re from ansible.module_utils.basic import * # NOQA # ConfigParser chokes on both mariadb and haproxy files. Luckily They have # a syntax approaching ini config file so they are relatively easy to parse. # This generic ini style config parser is not perfect -- it can ignore some # valid options -- but good enough for our use case. def generic_ini_style_conf_parser(file_path, section_regex, option_regex): config = {} current_section = None with open(file_path) as config_file: for line in config_file: match_section = re.match(section_regex, line) if match_section: current_section = match_section.group(1) config[current_section] = {} match_option = re.match(option_regex, line) if match_option and current_section: option = re.sub('\s+', ' ', match_option.group(1)) config[current_section][option] = match_option.group(2) return config def parse_haproxy_conf(file_path): section_regex = '^(\w+)' option_regex = '^(?:\s+)(\w+(?:\s+\w+)*?)\s+([\w/]*)$' return generic_ini_style_conf_parser(file_path, section_regex, option_regex) def main(): module = AnsibleModule(argument_spec=dict( path=dict(required=True, type='str'), )) haproxy_conf_path = module.params.get('path') try: config = parse_haproxy_conf(haproxy_conf_path) except IOError: module.fail_json(msg="Could not open the haproxy conf file at: '%s'" % haproxy_conf_path) module.exit_json(changed=False, ansible_facts={u'haproxy_conf': config}) if __name__ == '__main__': main()

commit_message:
Add the NoopFirewallDriver validation

When using Neutron for networking, the `firewall_driver` value in in
nova.conf must be set to NoopFirewallDriver.

Change-Id: I44e12d77a8e91bd7afab9acbae2080098a6799f4
(cherry picked from commit 8e311b6354cfaa1d62dc3594ed4f7d732c023913)

commit_message:
Drop MANIFEST.in - it's not needed by pbr

magnum-ui already uses PBR:-
setuptools.setup(
    setup_requires=['pbr>=1.8'],
    pbr=True)

This patch removes `MANIFEST.in` file as pbr generates a
sensible manifest from git files and some standard files
and it removes the need for an explicit `MANIFEST.in` file.

Change-Id: I4ed97d00cd5ead11f7b897bf715e14e6d54a6946

commit_message:
Add a validation-specific Ansible output callback

The validations have a few specifics in how they're used and what
information is important. So this formats the validation output in a way
that should highlight the failures themselves and make it more obvious
what went wrong and what to do when a validation fails.

Change-Id: I9730f2dd04868c5de46ae90bd545865d17aec530
Closes-Bug: #1625526
(cherry picked from commit e10338ce4adc99efe9e5764d7a4b85c5a5c6d883)

commit_message:
Remove temporary hack for translated releasenotes

The releasenotes conf.py files are fine now, we can remove the hack.

Instead test that the file is setup correctly and fail if not - that way
new projects *with* translations are forced to do this properly.

Change-Id: I38fdfac852c0b3007814d66f3c7cab87d6207c8c

commit_message:
Validate rogue DHCP servers

This adds two validations that check for unexpected DHCP servers in the
networks used for hardware introspection and provisioning.

Both validations depend on a file that sends a DHCP request for each
interface specified in its arguments and fails if there are any
responses.

Closes-Bug: #1620332
Change-Id: I22d4bf31e8f528e345b1a0a3ec972beea13d4f52
(cherry picked from commit 0a608f83bd9cd59b8744fc69807b8f0c7c9fc028)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations refs/changes/58/392858/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/tmp/validations-venv/bin/python # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. # Disable scapy's warning to stderr: import logging import sys logging.getLogger("scapy.runtime").setLevel(logging.ERROR) from scapy.all import BOOTP from scapy.all import conf from scapy.all import DHCP from scapy.all import Ether from scapy.all import get_if_raw_hwaddr from scapy.all import IP from scapy.all import srp from scapy.all import UDP def find_dhcp_servers(timeout_sec, interface): conf.checkIPaddr = False fam, hw = get_if_raw_hwaddr(interface) dhcp_discover = (Ether(dst="ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff") / IP(src="0.0.0.0", dst="255.255.255.255") / UDP(sport=68, dport=67) / BOOTP(chaddr=hw) / DHCP(options=[("message-type", "discover"), "end"])) ans, unans = srp(dhcp_discover, multi=True, timeout=timeout_sec, verbose=False) return [(unicode(packet[1][IP].src), packet[1][Ether].src) for packet in ans] def main(): dhcp_servers = [] for interface in sys.argv[1:]: dhcp_servers.extend(find_dhcp_servers(30, interface)) if dhcp_servers: sys.stderr.write('Found {} DHCP servers:'.format(len(dhcp_servers))) for ip, mac in dhcp_servers: sys.stderr.write("\n* {} ({})".format(ip, mac)) sys.exit(1) else: print("No DHCP servers found.") if __name__ == '__main__': main()

commit_message:
Add cross-repo job for fuel-ccp* projects

Jobs is expected to run for all fuel-ccp* base and component repos and
run script from fuel-ccp repo that currently is a simple script that
runs validation by cloning all masters, but it is expeted to be extended
with use of zuul-cloner for proper integration with Zuul.

Depends-On: Iaa9e6934d17c841c8c34e7f3b9c5e3197bac86c6
Change-Id: Ifb67b701c31d47ba3815c45d3e8fb87ac82cffde

commit_message:
Add fuel-ccp-galera project

Repository for clusted database solution in Fuel CCP based on Galera. We
start with empty repo and files to pass linters. Tests will be added in
first commit.

Change-Id: I68113f7911fe71467001aa353a47ade99d1f94fa

commit_message:
Restrict gate-tempest-dsvm-full-ubuntu-xenial to newton

The gate-tempest-dsvm-full-ubuntu-xenial job uses nova-network
which is deprecated since newton. In Ocata the default network
backend in jobs is going to be neutron and we need to start
removing jobs that use nova-network from Ocata runs. Since
gate-tempest-dsvm-full-ubuntu-xenial is in the integrated gate
it's a global job and this is a global cap so that it only
runs on stable/newton changes. As noted in the change, we'll
still have nova-network coverage in the cells v1 job in Ocata.

Change-Id: I3c13cb525da126e272789d0db6301f5e58c13b51
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/50/392950/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(mriedem): This job uses xenial nodes which restricts it to >= newton # changes. It also uses nova-network which is deprecated and not the default # in Ocata so we need to just restrict it to running on stable/newton # changes. nova-network in ocata will still have coverage on the cells v1 # job. branch: stable/newton

commit_message:
Rename gate-grenade-dsvm-multinode-live-migration-nv

This just adds -neutron- to the name to make it clear
that this job uses neutron as the network backend.

Otherwise it was easy to confuse this with gate-grenade-dsvm-multinode
which doesn't use neutron.

Change-Id: Ib7143bee9e8a159c53a972e83b10721a2142ce8f

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-02 19:32:47.000000000', 'files': ['jenkins/jobs/devstack-gate.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/458c143060ae6fbcb2c0bc13daeb9dcfc802d30f', 'message': "Explicitly set DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON=0 for nova-net grenade jobs

We're going to have conditional logic in devstack-gate for setting

commit_message:
Explicitly set DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON=0 for nova-net grenade jobs

We're going to have conditional logic in devstack-gate for setting
the default value of DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON. That will only set
the value from a default if not explicitly defined, and it's going
to change the default to enable neutron in Ocata.

This change explicitly sets DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON=0 in the
nova-network specific grenade jobs.

Note there are some other grenade jobs defined which don't specify
if neutron or nova-network should be used so they always relied
on the default in devstack-gate. So for grenade going from newton
to ocata those jobs will start using neutron, which is a change
and might work, or might not, but we'll have to explicitly define
the network backend to use, or cap those jobs based on branch, if
they don't work with neutron.

Change-Id: I33e8c81bb5366d2d1feccc144baa54ed3ed51e33
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/42/392942/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make the cells v1 job run explicitly with nova-network

The cells v1 job won't work with neutron, so it has to run
with nova-network. As we're looking to globally switch
DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON to 1 (the default) in devstack-gate
for the master branch (Ocata) if not specified, we need to
specify this for the cells v1 job.

See I6ece30e823c0cf21fbb2f37568c669dd7d3c6a08

Change-Id: If86b061be095ed5cfc7a5f5594f84abae68baab0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/38/392938/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(mriedem): Explicitly tell devstack-gate that we need to run # the cells v1 job with nova-network. export DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON=0

commit_message:
update trove ci for python-troveclient project

This change adds a skip on the test gate-trove-legacy-functional-* for
branches other than liberty, mitaka and newton.

It extends the logic that skips this for the trove project. I tried to
have two projects in the same skip-if but that didn't seem to work;
this one does seem to work.

Change-Id: I7a96bfead5b9cc69ebd27848b269d4f6353ba263

commit_message:
add non-voting multinode job for networking-odl carbon release

Multinode networking-odl setup test is required as part
of Neutron Stadium evolution [1]. Set to non-voting
untill upstream ODL issues are fixed and it's proven stable.

[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/networking-odl/+spec/
neutron-stadium-evolution

Change-Id: I090937d1eeb8892b95267f8a6ad11b9673f4140b
Closes-bug: #1633242

commit_message:
Add manila-test-image project

Add project to build test images for Manila. This new project is
an infra project (test/dev only) and GPLv2 licensed, due to it being
derived from buildroot, another GPLv2 licensed project.

Change-Id: I090bf4ff3b2d55f75e20f4d79ec5bf20d91198f4

commit_message:
remove wheel jobs from release queue

We do not need to run all of the wheel jobs every time we tag a
release, so remove them from that queue. We leave them in the periodic
queue for now, with the idea that we will move them to a higher
frequency in a separate patch, if needed.

Change-Id: I400c5c3df1229a9dd010babad539452e3e1404ab
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Remove unused trusty jobs from tempest zuul config

Tempest is branchless so all changes run against the
master branch which by definition only runs on xenial
nodes. So besides the liberty and mitaka compat jobs that
run on ubuntu trusty, we can remove all of these other
unused trusty jobs from the tempest zuul config.

Change-Id: Ib9a6be562b9c750deac7322c10587bcfce204f73

commit_message:
Enable proxy headers parsing for Neutron

http_proxy_to_wsgi middleware was recently added to Neutron [1] and
in order to take it into use, we need to enable it via hiera.

[1] Ice9ee8f4e04050271d59858f92034c230325718b
Depends-On: I99bc9486fdd85857ce73c413e17400320bd6ec5b
Related-Bug: #1590608

Change-Id: I10c065e726f2708e09acfc04dac3cae34a534d23

commit_message:
Add option to enable Neutron's SSL middleware

Neutron is now using the HTTPProxyToWSGI middleware from
oslo.middlware in its default api-paste configuration [1]. This commit
gives us the ability to enable/disable that middlware.

[1] Ice9ee8f4e04050271d59858f92034c230325718b

Change-Id: I99bc9486fdd85857ce73c413e17400320bd6ec5b

Add filters "policy_name" and "policy_type" for policy binding list

Revise cluster_policy_get_all, add policy_name and policy_type into
filter whitelist of ClusterPolicyController, add related unit test

Now 'fuel2 graph download' command can be executed without

behavior, i.e. plugins task level graph is downloading by default.
This patch fixes such behavior and makes task level parameters
mandatory, e.g.:
       fuel2 graph download [-h] -e ENV (-a | -c | -p | -r)

Change-Id: I5ed561cda9b0d35043822d01b6bb0b37df451fcb
"}]
commit_message:
Align parameters of 'fuel2 graph download' command

Now 'fuel2 graph download' command can be executed without
specifying any task level parameters that leads to erroneous
behavior, i.e. plugins task level graph is downloading by default.
This patch fixes such behavior and makes task level parameters
mandatory, e.g.:
       fuel2 graph download [-h] -e ENV (-a | -c | -p | -r)
                            [-t GRAPH_TYPE] [-f FILE]

Change-Id: I5ed561cda9b0d35043822d01b6bb0b37df451fcb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-fuelclient refs/changes/39/390639/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Dell SC: Add init_volume check and logging

Added a check to make sure the init_volume function uses
a physical server. Added a check and log message if the
volume was not able to be initialized.

Added a generic debug log message to find_volume.

Added a log message when the provider_id is no longer valid.

Change-Id: I385d3d8518ac5c60944f21d670f35e974eef28a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/77/391277/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if (scserver.get('status', 'down').lower() != 'down' and scserver.get('type', '').lower() == 'physical'): if not scvolume.get('active', False): LOG.error(_LE('init_volume failure: %r'), scvolume) LOG.debug('find_volume: name:%(name)r provider_id:%(id)r islv:%(lv)r', {'name': name, 'id': provider_id, 'lv': islivevol})

commit_message:
Replace deprecated RabbitMQ config from *.conf files

In nova.conf that was already corrected in commit
556e1abb001467bf57704e89d7fa1844cffc16cd
( https://review.openstack.org/#/c/389971/ ),
but with a spelling mistake, which is also fixed by this patch.

Change-Id: Ie1687cce60ed7ffcc9ecef407b0d7758834407be
Closes-Bug: #1637997

Add ZUUL_NEWREV to the AFS root-marker file that is used for publishing
content to the new AFS based docs site.

Backports: 905070527fe2a6157672fc1a75977d8d62ac9a87

commit_message:
Do not try to check for existing snapshots on Windows

There is no code to check for existing snapshots on Windows. Listing
them for that purpose just produces an error condition if the snapshot
does not exist (the common case) and the build aborts.

This patch removes the snapshot listing call from the Windows batch
files; it fixes a regression introduced with commit
3678ef2fa9893468604411ff697361bbd48d1e73.

Change-Id: I5df74d6e2efcabdf061cabe92d5da92d7a624740
Backports: 905070527fe2a6157672fc1a75977d8d62ac9a87
Closes-Bug: #1606766
Depends-On: I221cabdf5e9948dda81cefdff7c8f3b3ab96817c
(cherry picked from commit 730b7efed3ce542991a34f9cf2f083ae4f888e15)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-labs refs/changes/95/393095/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # On Windows, don't test; take snapshots unconditionally if ! WBATCH= vm_snapshot_exists "$vm_name" "$shot_name"; then

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-27 05:13:28.000000000', 'files': ['mistralclient/openstack/common/cliutils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-mistralclient/commit/82f22821c7fd0502c3272d46333ce8f2e2faf157', 'message': 'Fix python35 job failures

- inspect.getargspec()` was deprecated in Python 3.0 and will be removed
  in 3.6 (ETA late 2016). From Python 3.5 it started throwing a deprecation
  warning which leds some tests failures.

Change-Id: Ic57fd8629031a1a7a3e72b36bff133faf67544db
'}]
commit_message:
Fix python35 job failures

- inspect.getargspec()` was deprecated in Python 3.0 and will be removed
  in 3.6 (ETA late 2016). From Python 3.5 it started throwing a deprecation
  warning which leds some tests failures.

Change-Id: Ic57fd8629031a1a7a3e72b36bff133faf67544db
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-mistralclient refs/changes/25/391025/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: argspec = list(inspect.signature(fn).parameters.keys()) num_defaults = len(argspec or []) required_args = argspec[:len(argspec) - num_defaults]
deleted_lines: argspec = inspect.getargspec(fn) num_defaults = len(argspec.defaults or []) required_args = argspec.args[:len(argspec.args) - num_defaults]

Update .coveragerc after the removal of openstack directory

we have retired oslo-incubator,so don't use this directory any more.

commit_message:
Fix keystone,database,memcache for k8s.

Modify keystone,database,memcache,openvswitch, assignment to support kolla-k8s deployment.
Such as:
keystone_admin_url: "{{ admin_protocol }}://{{ kolla_internal_fqdn if orchestration_engine == 'ANSIBLE' else 'keystone-admin' }}:{{ keystone_admin_port }}/v3"

glance_database_address: "{% if orchestration_engine == 'ANSIBLE' %}{{ kolla_internal_fqdn }}{% else %}mariadb{% endif %}:{{ database_port }}"

Closes-Bug: #1624830

Change-Id: Ib8a53f13509057432ecd2c9aac64a66cd292747e

commit_message:
To fix miscellaneous bugs in OVOs

1) In cinder/objects/qos_specs.py
the OPTIONAL_FIELDS is part of the class definition,
_from_db_object should no longer be a staticmethod,
 but should be a classmethod
2) Same issue fixed in cinder/objects/snapshot.py
3) cinder/api/views/qos_specs.py
The comma missing in dictionary definition
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/251989/27/cinder/api/views/qos_specs.py@44

Change-Id: I94977ffdd1dce5a44f19c1d35422cb37b54f8d25
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/96/391996/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @classmethod def _from_db_object(cls, context, snapshot, db_snapshot, expected_attrs=None): if name in cls.OPTIONAL_FIELDS:
deleted_lines: @staticmethod def _from_db_object(context, snapshot, db_snapshot, expected_attrs=None): if name in Snapshot.OPTIONAL_FIELDS:

Currently, when there are some qemu processes which may be some useful
virtual machines running by the operator running on non compute node, the
cleanup script will fail the cleanup operation for that node. We need to

Closes-bug: 1633005

commit_message:
Cleanup container script improvement

Currently, when there are some qemu processes which may be some useful
virtual machines running by the operator running on non compute node, the
cleanup script will fail the cleanup operation for that node. We need to
ignore the qemu process check for non compute nodes.

Change-Id: If49a1a30764063935b2a65312de8f3b2357c7fbc
Closes-bug: 1633005
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/60/385860/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: - name: Destroying all Kolla containers and volumes

commit_message:
Use InvalidCredentials exception from correct path

InvalidCredentials is in tempest/lib/exceptions.py, not in
tempest/exceptions.py. This patch is to use it from correct path.

Change-Id: I2319dce4f1b5a18707b1e7b51635f4f9e93494be

by using groupby tenant_id,res_type

commit_message:
Bad error reporting on config permissions error

there are two kinds of configurations: single config file(xx.conf) and
config files under config dir(xx.conf.d).

swift will report a permissions error when it can't read single config
file:

  Error trying to load config from /etc/swift/object-server/2.conf:
  [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/etc/swift/object-server/2.conf'

But it will not report permission errors when trying to read files from
a config directory.

This patch fixes the latter by printing a warning when it can't read
files under a config directory. Allowing us to locate the error.

For example:

  $ pwd
  /etc/swift/object-server/1.conf.d

  $ swift-init object start -c 1
  WARNING: Unable to modify file descriptor limit. Running as non-root?
  Warning: Read permission denied: \
  /etc/swift/object-server/1.conf.d/bind.conf

  Starting object-server...(/etc/swift/object-server/1.conf.d)
  bind_port wasn't properly set in the config file. It must be \
  explicitly set to a valid port number.

Change-Id: I57d345158189a4738da10bcbe515c06eb527004d
Closes-bug: #1535839
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/25/273325/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import glob if os.path.isdir(conf_file): if os.access(conf_file, os.X_OK): denied_files = [sub_conf_file for sub_conf_file in glob.glob(os.path.join(conf_file, "*.conf")) if os.path.isfile(sub_conf_file) and not os.access(sub_conf_file, os.R_OK)] if denied_files: print (_('Warning: Read permission denied: %s') % ', '.join(denied_files)) else: print(_("Warning: Dir %s should be executable") % conf_file)

commit_message:
Make NullLogger more logger like

eventlet.wsgi.server is adaptive to dealing with the named log
argument being either a file like or a log like [1], but message
handling is a more direct pass through if it's a log like.

Since all we want to do is make eventlet's logging it a noop - it's
easy to provide either interface!

1. https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/4d2cdc/eventlet/wsgi.py#L246

Change-Id: I2d792176c96931eafb3f140e6653ba8b31eda429

commit_message:
Use more specific asserts in test/probe tests

I changed asserts with more specific assert methods.

e.g.: from assertTrue(sth == None) to assertIsNone(*) or
assertTrue(isinstance(inst, type)) to assertIsInstace(inst, type) or
assertTrue(not sth) to assertFalse(sth).

The code gets more readable, and a better description will be shown on fail.

Change-Id: I3768faa568e3964e726ecc48ac8cb133cb088284

commit_message:
host_info: fix has_plugin/get_plugin methods on HostInfo

The HostPluginInfo object had its property renamed from
"name" to "plugin_name" during review, but we missed
updates to HostInfo to take account of this.

commit_message:
Allow Barbican Secret Payload to be Stored via File

Allows Barbican Cli's 'Barbican Secret Store'
command to allow a payload to be set via a file.

Change-Id: Ib3f69d333ef1b82c96cdda81d0b3b1823b7e644f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-barbicanclient refs/changes/35/242635/22 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from barbicanclient.common import utils def update(self, secret_ref, payload=None, file_path=None): :param str: file_path: Path to file containing payload # Payload should only be specified through input or file, not both if payload and file_path: raise exceptions.HTTPClientError('Cannot specify both payload ' 'and file-path') # Payload or file_path must be input if not (payload or file_path): raise exceptions.HTTPClientError('Please specify either payload ' 'or file-path') if file_path: blob = utils.read_blob_file_contents(file_path) try: payload = blob except ValueError as e: raise exceptions.PayloadException(e)

commit_message:
Remove custom OVS compilation trigger for Openstack CI

Compiling a fresh upstream OVS is not required anymore now
that our tempest job is configured to use xenial.

(Note that the devstack-gate-bagpipe-rc script is only used by the
Openstack CI gate scripts so removing the OVS compilation trigger
does not impact non-gate use of the devstack plugin)

Change-Id: I50f2b6275400877e6e727a435406e362390dad46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-bgpvpn refs/changes/54/392154/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Revert "Start network connections after neutron forks workers"

This reverts commit c807cd6c8a8f766cd1296b38eab21f296dfbd412.

My env is using redis.

With the commit, neutron-server can write data to nb db, but the df
controller can't get the notification. We may need to find another way
out. But revert the commit seems to be a quick fix.

Change-Id: I21c4aa2f155d7ef99e5c4efad59146514bd9f944
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/13/393013/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adds styled 404 error page for developer.openstack.org migrating to AFS

- Also templatizes the Google Analytics code snippet for
consistency with openstack-manuals for ease of maintenance.

Change-Id: I7b1e1a1dfe894ee71ba2c973488a224a699c0166

commit_message:
Set upper constraint to kombu

The lastest 4.0.0 kombu release causes gate failures in unit
tests due to some incompatible changes. Now we should set
kombu<4.0.0 to resolve the issue.

Change-Id: If02240b9c0c1e9cf9dee7368f23beb9840e3686d
Closes-Bug: #1638323

commit_message:
Trivial: Remove redundant variable

As I5b077f403e22ce1ff6833bc397afd21bf4d3e498, we can
simply do self.***['id'] instead of create a new variable. But
some other files are also the case. This patch changes these files
to make the code consistent.

Change-Id: Id317f81362a2c066994cc3385c2401494382de6e

deleted_lines: @test.attr(type='smoke') def test_datasource_db_sync_add(self): # Verify that a replica adds a datasource when a datasource # appears in the database. client1 = self.admin_manager.congress_client # delete fake if it exists. old_fake_id = self.find_fake(client1) if old_fake_id: client1.delete_datasource(old_fake_id) # Verify that primary server has no fake datasource if not test.call_until_true( func=lambda: self.datasource_missing(client1, old_fake_id), duration=60, sleep_for=1): raise exceptions.TimeoutException( "primary should not have fake, but does") need_to_delete_fake = False try: # Create a new fake datasource fake_id = self.create_fake(client1) need_to_delete_fake = True # Verify that primary server has fake datasource if not test.call_until_true( func=lambda: self.datasource_exists(client1, fake_id), duration=60, sleep_for=1): raise exceptions.TimeoutException( "primary should have fake, but does not") # start replica self.start_replica(CONF.congressha.replica_port) # Create session for second server. client2 = self.create_client(CONF.congressha.replica_type) # Verify that second server has fake datasource if not test.call_until_true( func=lambda: self.datasource_exists(client2, fake_id), duration=60, sleep_for=1): raise exceptions.TimeoutException( "replica should have fake, but does not") # Remove fake from primary server instance. LOG.debug("removing fake datasource %s", str(fake_id)) client1.delete_datasource(fake_id) need_to_delete_fake = False # Confirm that fake is gone from primary server instance. if not test.call_until_true( func=lambda: self.datasource_missing(client1, fake_id), duration=60, sleep_for=1): self.stop_replica(CONF.congressha.replica_port) raise exceptions.TimeoutException( "primary instance still has fake") LOG.debug("removed fake datasource from primary instance") # Confirm that second service instance removes fake. if not test.call_until_true( func=lambda: self.datasource_missing(client2, fake_id), duration=60, sleep_for=1): raise exceptions.TimeoutException( "replica should remove fake, but still has it") finally: self.stop_replica(CONF.congressha.replica_port) if need_to_delete_fake: self.admin_manager.congress_client.delete_datasource(fake_id)

commit_message:
Add external hiera override hierarchy levels

Additional hierarchy levels can be added to
"/etc/hiera/external" with a r10k friendly structure.

These levels can be used to apply overrides from the
external repository either per-environment or for
the default production environemnt.

Overrides can be applies either for every node,
or for the roles group from the "roles" facts, or
globally and per-cluster.

Change-Id: Ia9e0bf6213ce616e96f7c3598a362e1978f48e2a
Related-Bug: 1618139
Rally-Id: US763570

commit_message:
local HA tests

Added some local HAHT tests
- unit tests no longer work concurrently
- bindep.txt added for binary dependencies needed for tests

Closes-Bug: 1600019
Partially implements blueprint: high-availability-design

Change-Id: If4213ede7bde4d78d710ce75c0147a4889387da9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/27/358927/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Note: monkey patch to allow running this test standalone under 'nose' import eventlet eventlet.monkey_patch() class TestCongressHA(base.SqlTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestCongressHA, self).setUp() # setup PE node 1 services = api_base.setup_config(with_fake_datasource=False, node_id='pe_node1') self.api1 = services['api'] self.node1 = services['node'] self.engine1 = services['engine'] # del self.node1.sync_thread # FIXME(ekcs): temp hack disable sync self.api = self.api1 self.node = self.node1 self.engine = self.engine1 self.services = services # setup PE node 2 services = api_base.setup_config(with_fake_datasource=False, node_id='pe_node2', same_partition_as_node=self.node1) self.api2 = services['api'] self.node2 = services['node'] self.engine2 = services['engine'] # del self.node2.sync_thread # FIXME(ekcs): temp hack disable sync # setup DSD node self.nodeDSD = helper.make_dsenode_same_partition(self.node1, 'dsd_node') self.neutronv2 = self._create_neutron_mock('neutron') def _create_neutron_mock(self, name): # Register Neutron service args = helper.datasource_openstack_args() neutronv2 = neutronv2_driver.NeutronV2Driver(name, args=args) # FIXME(ekcs): this is a hack to prevent the synchronizer from # attempting to delete this DSD because it's not in DB # neutronv2.type = 'no_sync_datasource_driver' self.nodeDSD.register_service(neutronv2) neutron_mock = mock.MagicMock( spec=neutronclient.v2_0.client.Client) neutronv2.neutron = neutron_mock # initialize neutron_mocks network1 = test_neutron.network_response port_response = test_neutron.port_response router_response = test_neutron.router_response sg_group_response = test_neutron.security_group_response neutron_mock.list_networks.return_value = network1 neutron_mock.list_ports.return_value = port_response neutron_mock.list_routers.return_value = router_response neutron_mock.list_security_groups.return_value = sg_group_response return neutronv2 def setup_config(self): args = ['--config-file', helper.etcdir('congress.conf.test')] config.init(args) def test_startup(self): self.assertIsNotNone(self.services['api']) self.assertIsNotNone(self.services[harness.ENGINE_SERVICE_NAME]) self.assertIsNotNone( self.services[harness.ENGINE_SERVICE_NAME].node) def test_policy(self): self.create_policy('alpha') self.insert_rule('q(1, 2) :- true', 'alpha') self.insert_rule('q(2, 3) :- true', 'alpha') helper.retry_check_function_return_value( lambda: sorted(self.query('q', 'alpha')['results'], key=lambda x: x['data']), sorted([{'data': (1, 2)}, {'data': (2, 3)}], key=lambda x: x['data'])) helper.retry_check_function_return_value( lambda: list(self.query('q', 'alpha').keys()), ['results']) def test_policy_datasource(self): self.create_policy('alpha') self.create_fake_datasource('fake') data = self.node.service_object('fake') data.state = {'fake_table': set([(1, 2)])} data.poll() self.insert_rule('q(x) :- fake:fake_table(x,y)', 'alpha') helper.retry_check_function_return_value( lambda: self.query('q', 'alpha'), {'results': [{'data': (1,)}]}) # TODO(dse2): enable rules to be inserted before data created. # Maybe just have subscription handle errors gracefull when # asking for a snapshot and return []. # self.insert_rule('p(x) :- fake:fake_table(x)', 'alpha') def create_policy(self, name): self.api['api-policy'].add_item({'name': name}, {}) def insert_rule(self, rule, policy): context = {'policy_id': policy} return self.api['api-rule'].add_item( {'rule': rule}, {}, context=context) def create_fake_datasource(self, name): item = {'name': name, 'driver': 'fake_datasource', 'description': 'hello world!', 'enabled': True, 'type': None, 'config': {'auth_url': 'foo', 'username': 'armax', 'password': '<hidden>', 'tenant_name': 'armax'}} return self.api['api-datasource'].add_item(item, params={}) def query(self, tablename, policyname): context = {'policy_id': policyname, 'table_id': tablename} return self.api['api-row'].get_items({}, context) def test_rule_insert_delete(self): self.api['api-policy'].add_item({'name': 'alice'}, {}) context = {'policy_id': 'alice'} (id1, _) = self.api['api-rule'].add_item( {'rule': 'p(x) :- plus(y, 1, x), q(y)'}, {}, context=context) ds = self.api['api-rule'].get_items({}, context)['results'] self.assertEqual(len(ds), 1) self.api['api-rule'].delete_item(id1, {}, context) ds = self.engine.policy_object('alice').content() self.assertEqual(len(ds), 0) def test_rule_insert_delete_multinode(self): self.api['api-policy'].add_item({'name': 'alice'}, {}) context = {'policy_id': 'alice'} (id1, _) = self.api['api-rule'].add_item( {'rule': 'p(x) :- plus(y, 1, x), q(y)'}, {}, context=context) self.engine2.synchronize_policies() self.engine2.synchronize_rules() ds = self.api['api-rule'].get_items({}, context)['results'] self.assertEqual(len(ds), 1) # helper.retry_check_function_return_value( # lambda: len(self.api2['api-rule'].get_items({}, context)['results']), 1) self.api['api-rule'].delete_item(id1, {}, context) ds = self.engine.policy_object('alice').content() self.assertEqual(len(ds), 0) def test_datasource_request_refresh(self): # neutron polls automatically here, which is why register_service # starts its service. neutron = self.neutronv2 neutron.stop() self.assertEqual(neutron.refresh_request_queue.qsize(), 0) neutron.request_refresh() self.assertEqual(neutron.refresh_request_queue.qsize(), 1) neutron.start() neutron.request_refresh() f = lambda: neutron.refresh_request_queue.qsize() helper.retry_check_function_return_value(f, 0) def test_datasource_poll(self): neutron = self.neutronv2 neutron.stop() neutron._translate_ports({'ports': []}) self.assertEqual(len(neutron.state['ports']), 0) neutron.start() f = lambda: len(neutron.state['ports']) helper.retry_check_function_return_value_not_eq(f, 0)

subject: Remove deprecated ansible_ssh_host variable
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-25 19:37:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_magnum/commit/94c5e7b06808ddeb8ed8ca5ce4f08d5fa256c772', 'message': "Remove depricated ansible_ssh_host variable

This changes 'ansible_ssh_host' to 'ansible_host'. The 'ansible_ssh_host'
variable has been depricated as noted here: [0].

[0] - http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/intro_inventory.html#hosts-and-groups

Change-Id: I06c26bc22ecbbbd7e858027a6b7fef22316efa22

commit_message:
Remove deprecated ansible_ssh_host variable

This changes 'ansible_ssh_host' to 'ansible_host'. The 'ansible_ssh_host'
variable has been deprecated as noted here: [0].

[0] - http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/intro_inventory.html#hosts-and-groups

Change-Id: I06c26bc22ecbbbd7e858027a6b7fef22316efa22
Related-Bug: #1636606
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-27 01:24:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/117cfcb38ce3e7d1f31764b0a68b4ccb9c7dba05', 'message': "Disable 'accept_ras' in DHCP agent namespace

The DHCP agent explicitly assigns address to the agent
based on the data model. Change
I85ef1f4d60efd0309d6a0706e29fdbcc16f0b59d made it so it
does this for IPv6 stateless networks as well to function
correctly with metadata. However, this opened a race condition
where the DHCP namespace may get an RA address before a permanent
address is assigned to it. If this happened, DHCP would be broken

the agent to get an RA address when we now statically give it

commit_message:
Disable 'accept_ra' in DHCP agent namespace

The DHCP agent explicitly assigns address to the agent
based on the data model. Change
I85ef1f4d60efd0309d6a0706e29fdbcc16f0b59d made it so it
does this for IPv6 stateless networks as well to function
correctly with metadata. However, this opened a race condition
where the DHCP namespace may get an RA address before a permanent
address is assigned to it. If this happened, DHCP would be broken
for that network since the agent couldn't successfully assign the
address it wanted to the interface due to a conflict with the RA
address.

This patch disables RA in the DHCP namespace. There is no need for
the agent to get an RA address when we now statically give it
addresses. This also effectively reverts the fix in
I72b85eb93d1849299d523eedf563ab201b4a0352 since we now correctly
handle auto addressed subnets.

Closes-Bug: #1627902
Change-Id: I8684370ff1ad9387d0e2f450ce483b22b613a3c7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/40/377140/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from neutron.common import ipv6_utils if not ipv6_utils.is_slaac_subnet(subnet): net = netaddr.IPNetwork(subnet.cidr) ip_cidr = '%s/%s' % (fixed_ip.ip_address, net.prefixlen) ip_cidrs.append(ip_cidr)

subject: Swift proxy performance fixes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-01 11:31:56.000000000', 'files': ['templates/proxy-server.conf.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_swift/commit/d409a50c9bb795b2129fdb83a248b32d0b1b7279', 'message': 'Swift proxy performance fixes

Performance testing of an OSA deployed Swift cluster hit several issues.
Comparison of the proxy conf with the Swift Auth doc [1] found
two settings that affect performance that that were not set in the template.

include_service_catalog - This defaults to True which makes the proxy server
fetch the service catalog on every request in the authtoken middleware. This
hammers Keystone.

cache - When using memcache this should be set so the authtoken middleware
uses the correct cache and not go back to Keystone on every request.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/overview_auth.html

Change-Id: Iddaf097e3ff5c1b7118b11cfc598a40a91d6f96f
(cherry picked from commit b0f330e7b2a805c87a988d1cd312ec766e5e9f39)
(cherry picked from commit 621c821867ac1cd42dd40871d03c853536551728)
'}]
commit_message:
Swift proxy performance fixes

Performance testing of an OSA deployed Swift cluster hit several issues.
Comparison of the proxy conf with the Swift Auth doc [1] found
two settings that affect performance that that were not set in the template.

include_service_catalog - This defaults to True which makes the proxy server
fetch the service catalog on every request in the authtoken middleware. This
hammers Keystone.

cache - When using memcache this should be set so the authtoken middleware
uses the correct cache and not go back to Keystone on every request.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/swift/overview_auth.html

Change-Id: Iddaf097e3ff5c1b7118b11cfc598a40a91d6f96f
(cherry picked from commit b0f330e7b2a805c87a988d1cd312ec766e5e9f39)
(cherry picked from commit 621c821867ac1cd42dd40871d03c853536551728)

commit_message:
Files with no code must be left completely empty

As per OpenStack licensing guide lines [1]:
[H104] Files with no code shouldn't contain any license header nor
comments, and must be left completely empty.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#openstack-licensing

Change-Id: I2df3d796aabbd2d283520b207bee3a80e663ecb4

commit_message:
Remove hard-coded host group

A previous commit added a hard-coded host group to
rabbitmq-install.yml, instead of using the variable rabbitmq_host_group.
This commit updates rabbitmq-install.yml to use rabbitmq_host_group
instead.

commit_message:
Use FIXED_RANGE(_V6) as default subnet pool range

It turns out that many people have already chosen fixed ranges that work
for their environments. They have done so to avoid conflicts with
existing networking ranges and routing. The change to use 10.0.0.0/8 and
apply routes for this network to neutron interfaces prevents anyone from
using networks within that range for anything else.

For example imagine you have a cloud provider that provides private IPv4
addresses allocated out of ranges in 10.0.0.0/8 and they do all public
networking over ipv6. This change to devstack prevents you from using
those private networks properly after starting neutron with devstack.
However, in situations like this FIXED_RANGE should already represent a
safe range to use so just use it.

FIXED_RANGE_V6 is also increased to a /56 so that individual /64s can
be allocated for tenant networks.

Co-Authored-By: Sean M. Collins <sean@coreitpro.com>

Change-Id: I9f44803cf04b572074bdb4b97ee58827c5611514

commit_message:
WIP: Add expand/contract commands to glance-manage CLI.

The parent of this patch introduced the change to Alembic-based
migrations. This commit builds on top of that by adding expand
and contract commands to the glance-manage tool. Appropriate
documentation is updated and failing tests are adjusted to accomodate
the new database versioning schema.

Change-Id: Ib232a4217bf2716574edac2b4f912d4e127118d5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/78/390678/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: glance-manage db sync [VERSION]specified VERSION or to the latest migration level if VERSION is not specified. .. note:: Prior to Ocata release the database version was a numeric value. For example: for the Newton release, the latest migration level was ``44``. Starting with Ocata, the version will be a named value corresponding to a particular release. For the Ocata release, the latest migration level is ``ocata_expand01``. Furthermore, after completing the full upgrade process, a databse may have multiple latest versions. For example: ``ocata_expand01``, ``ocata_contract01``.Expanding the Database ---------------------- glance-manage db expand This will run the expansion phase of a rolling upgrade process. Contracting the Database ---------------------- glance-manage db contract This will run the contraction phase of a rolling upgrade process.

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-17 19:16:07.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_volumes.py', 'nova/api/openstack/compute/legacy_v2/contrib/volumes.py', 'nova/api/openstack/compute/volumes.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a967cfe37a3bc26ee8a8517d5f5dac33b35e377e', 'message': 'Fix error status code on update-volume API

As the following part of API-WG guidline[1],

  If a request contains a reference to a nonexistent resource in the
  body (not URI), the code should be 400 Bad Request. Do not use 404
  NotFound because :rfc:`7231#section-6.5.4` (section 6.5.4) mentions
  the origin server did not find a current representation for the
  target resource for 404 and representation for the target resource
  means a URI

Nova should return a BadRequest response(400) in this case, because
new_volume_id is specified in a request body. old_volume_id is not
necessary to be changed because the value is specified with URI.
So it is valid to return NotFound response if that is not existent.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/api-wg/blob/master/guidelines/http.rst#failure-code-clarifications

Close-Bug: #1629110

commit_message:
Fix error status code on update-volume API

As the following part of API-WG guidline[1],

  If a request contains a reference to a nonexistent resource in the
  body (not URI), the code should be 400 Bad Request. Do not use 404
  NotFound because :rfc:`7231#section-6.5.4` (section 6.5.4) mentions
  the origin server did not find a current representation for the
  target resource for 404 and representation for the target resource
  means a URI

Nova should return a BadRequest response(400) in this case, because
new_volume_id is specified in a request body. old_volume_id is not
necessary to be changed because the value is specified with URI.
So it is valid to return NotFound response if that is not existent.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/api-wg/blob/master/guidelines/http.rst#failure-code-clarifications

Close-Bug: #1629110
Change-Id: Ib781b116f5af713d64b5880858cc4f81c3da3977
(cherry picked from commit edd86d9dac1ea75bc580a7964e7d699ee9644b19)
(cherry picked from commit 4e6958551c324635a8720fc9125e9596860637f7)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/44/387644/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: new_volume_id = body['volumeAttachment']['volumeId'] try: new_volume = self.volume_api.get(context, new_volume_id) except exception.VolumeNotFound as e: # NOTE: This BadRequest is different from the above NotFound even # though the same VolumeNotFound exception. This is intentional # because new_volume_id is specified in a request body and if a # nonexistent resource in the body (not URI) the code should be # 400 Bad Request as API-WG guideline. On the other hand, # old_volume_id is specified with URI. So it is valid to return # NotFound response if that is not existent. raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=e.format_message())

commit_message:
Create heat user in keystone profile

Rather than use the heat::keystone::domain class which also includes the
configuration options, we should just create the user for heat in
keystone independently of the configuration.

Change-Id: I7d42d04ef0c53dc1e62d684d8edacfed9fd28fbe
Related-Bug: #1638350
Closes-Bug: #1638626
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/88/392288/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $heat_admin_domain = hiera('heat::keystone::domain::domain_name', 'heat'), $heat_admin_user = hiera('heat::keystone::domain::domain_admin', 'heat_admin'), $heat_admin_email = hiera('heat::keystone::domain::domain_admin_email', 'heat_admin@localhost'), $heat_admin_password = hiera('heat::keystone::domain::domain_password', 'changeme'), # create these seperate and don't use ::heat::keystone::domain since # that class writes out the configs keystone_domain { $heat_admin_domain: ensure => 'present', enabled => true } keystone_user { "${heat_admin_user}::${heat_admin_domain}": ensure => 'present', enabled => true, email => $heat_admin_email, password => $heat_admin_password } keystone_role { "${heat_admin_user}::${heat_admin_domain}@::${heat_admin_domain}": roles => ['admin'] require => Class['::heat::roles::admin'] }
deleted_lines: # if Heat and Keystone are collocated, so we want to # both configure heat.conf and create Keystone resources. # note: domain_password is given via Hiera. if defined(Class['::tripleo::profile::base::heat']) { include ::heat::keystone::domain } else { # if Heat and Keystone are not collocated, we want Puppet # to only create Keystone resources on the Keystone node # but not try to configure Heat, to avoid leaking the password. class { '::heat::keystone::domain': domain_name => $::os_service_default, domain_admin => $::os_service_default, domain_password => $::os_service_default, } } Class['::keystone::roles::admin'] -> Class['::heat::keystone::domain']

commit_message:
Update upgrade instructions for M->N upgrades

Update the documentations with the additional steps needed
for an M->N upgrades.

 * Document ceilometer wsgi pre upgrade step
 * Document aodh data migration post converge step

We should address the following in a later commit:
- Some more details upstream about ceph jewel repos
- IgnoreCephWarnings notice when using only one ceph node

Closes-Bug: #1628551
Co-Authored-By: Marios Andreou <marios@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I8ebf5a4e05271666de6f4044a2781b503649333f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/17/384717/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. admonition:: Mitaka to Newton :class: ltom **Deliver the migration for ceilometer to run under httpd.** This is to deliver the migration for ceilometer to be run under httpd (apache) rather than eventlet as was the case before. To execute this step run `overcloud deploy`, passing in the full set of environment files plus `major-upgrade-ceilometer-wsgi-mitaka-newton.yaml`:: openstack overcloud deploy --templates \ -e <full environment> \ -e /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/environments/major-upgrade-ceilometer-wsgi-mitaka-newton.yaml .. admonition:: Mitaka to Newton :class: ltom **Deliver the data migration for aodh.** This is to deliver the data migration for aodh. To execute this step run `overcloud deploy`, passing in the full set of environment files plus `major-upgrade-aodh-migration.yaml`:: openstack overcloud deploy --templates \ -e <full environment> \ -e /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/environments/major-upgrade-aodh-migration.yaml

commit_message:
Use centralised Ansible test scripts

This patch consumes the centralised Ansible test scripts
implemented in https://review.openstack.org/381853

Change-Id: I71328a0d24eec716232a227ce52c63e25102ae46

commit_message:
Replace 'MagicMock' with 'Mock'

MagicMock magically allow things to pass. Any usage should
be replaced with the Mock class and explicit attributes
should be set on it. [1]
[1] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/17181687/mock-vs-magicmock

Change-Id: I0e78443825c9204d180ac369d52780a2a5352a89

subject: Move diskimage-image-create to an entry point
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-08 07:53:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/5a47d0b0063ed8967ef7d55184cdfbfc0871a5f9', 'message': "Move diskimage-image-create to an entry point

It has always been a weird thing that dib is a python package, but
is totally driven by the disk-image-create script.  It creates this
strange division that is hard to explain.

This moves disk-image-create to a regular python entry-point

Currently, this simply exec()s the original disk-image-create script.

However, we now have a (private) interface between disk-image-create
written in python and the driver shell script.  Here's some things we
could do, for example:

* Argument parsing is generally nicer in Python, and then end result
  is mostly just setting environment variables to flag different things
  in the shell script.  I could see us moving the argument-parsing into
  diskimage_builder.disk_image_create:main() and just setting things in
  os.environ before the exec()).

* I7092e1845942f249175933d67ab121188f3511fd sets IMAGE_ELEMENT_YAML in
  disk-image-create by calling-back to element-info.  We can just call
  element_dependencies.find_all_elements() in here an export is to
  os.environ before disk-image-create starts.

* remove need for ramdisk-image-create symlink by just exporting
  IS_RAMDISK based on sys.argv[1] value

* you could even unit test some of this :)

Change-Id: I69ca3d26fede0506a6353c077c69f735c8d84d28

commit_message:
Move diskimage-image-create to an entry point

It has always been a weird thing that dib is a python package, but
is totally driven by the disk-image-create script.  It creates this
strange division that is hard to explain.

This moves disk-image-create to a regular python entry-point

Currently, this simply exec()s the original disk-image-create script.

However, we now have a (private) interface between disk-image-create
written in python and the driver shell script.  Here's some things we
could do, for example:

* Argument parsing is generally nicer in Python, and then end result
  is mostly just setting environment variables to flag different things
  in the shell script.  I could see us moving the argument-parsing into
  diskimage_builder.disk_image_create:main() and just setting things in
  os.environ before the exec()).

* I7092e1845942f249175933d67ab121188f3511fd sets IMAGE_ELEMENT_YAML in
  disk-image-create by calling-back to element-info.  We can just call
  element_dependencies.find_all_elements() in here an export is to
  os.environ before disk-image-create starts.

* remove need for ramdisk-image-create symlink by just exporting
  IS_RAMDISK based on sys.argv[1] value

* you could even unit test some of this :)

Change-Id: I69ca3d26fede0506a6353c077c69f735c8d84d28

commit_message:
Remove conductor local api:s and 'use_local' config option

This change removes the deprecated conductor local mode and the
'use_local' flag that was used to control it.

UpgradeImpact

Change-Id: Icc1624606ecb561781a971467443e24b1643f535
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/96/387996/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- upgrade: - | The ''use_local'' option, which made it possible to perform nova-conductor operations locally, has been removed. This legacy mode was introduced to bridge a gap during the transition to the conductor service. It no longer represents a reasonable alternative for deployers.

commit_message:
Cleanup before removal of conductor local apis

Some old cruft from the when conductor proxying was being used to
make db calls are left in various places in unit tests. None of this
is of use anymore and needs to be removed before the conductor local
apis and related 'use_local' flag can be removed.

Change-Id: Id5fe30f4124396ac59ef3d008972db4dd930855d

subject: Block kombu 4.0.0
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-02 15:06:52.000000000', 'files': ['global-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/68d10af6e1c11c818b4419a466cb6e0b9c060a55', 'message': "Block kombu 4.0.0

oslo.messaging is not compatible with it, for two reasons: because we
cap amqp<2.0.0 there; and because the code of the library needs some
adjustments.

Until we clear that up, we will block the new  kombu release. We don't
cap because it's against the direction we want to take long term
(adopting to new upstream releases).

Change-Id: I34e0ca49966d679ff60d4bcfbf7157c6289a9aef
Related-Bug: #1638263
"}]
commit_message:
Block kombu 4.0.0

oslo.messaging is not compatible with it, for two reasons: because we
cap amqp<2.0.0 there; and because the code of the library needs some
adjustments.

Until we clear that up, we will block the new  kombu release. We don't
cap because it's against the direction we want to take long term
(adopting to new upstream releases).

Change-Id: I34e0ca49966d679ff60d4bcfbf7157c6289a9aef
Related-Bug: #1638263

commit_message:
tempest HAHT wait for sync

Add a wait timer in tests that rely on replicated nodes to sync.
With this change, the gate-congress-pe-replicated-nv test is
expected to pass and this provides useful feedback.
Note: the existing retry logic do not work for some reason.
But we don't fix the retry logic because retry is undesirable for
this kind of testing (explained in comment).

Change-Id: Ic9adc1ddcb1e86e5ab75d1154b8bfa45b51f3fa1

commit_message:
Fix AdminPassword for overcloud during upgrades

In newton the password generation moved to a workflow.  In the case
when an overcloud is upgraded from mitaka to newton, the previous
OS_PASSWORD/AdminPassword should be respected if found in the
environment.

This is a one cycle fix that should be immediately considered
as deprecated and will be removed in ocata as upgrades from
newton to ocata should both use the password generation workflow.

Closes-Bug: 1638003
Change-Id: I05dbbe61f3ff8da182739aa41512b76fc86cb7a6
backport: newton
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/01/391201/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE (rbrady): In the case of an upgrade from mitaka -> newton # the current AdminPassword should remain the same. This fix # should be considered immediately deprecated and will be removed # later in ocata as newton -> ocata upgrades should both use the # passwords generated in the workflow. overcloud_admin_password = os.environ.get('OS_PASSWORD') if overcloud_admin_password: __password_cache['AdminPassword'] = overcloud_admin_password

commit_message:
Fix test_revoke to run all tests after pki removal

The recent change [1] caused the removal of a certain class that
looked specific to PKI and PKIz testing and implementation, however,
actually was being used to test all supported token providers. This
caused a chunk of tests to simply not run at all and therefore be
overlooked. This change adds support for both UUID and Fernet so that
all tests are being run once again and for all available token
providers.

[1]: Icf1ebced44a675c88fb66a6c0431208ff5181574
Change-Id: I5365e2ed74ea55377729d0910cc2892d2bb8889c

commit_message:
Enable DeprecationWarning in test environments

Many deprecations are triggered early (on imports, for example).
To make sure all DeprecationWarning messages are emitted we enable
them via the PYTHONWARNINGS environment variable.

Change-Id: I3916ed3a40c0a5ba08c0528ae586554344539df2
Note: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/379581/
      https://review.openstack.org/#/c/353154/

commit_message:
Enable DeprecationWarning in test environments

Many deprecations are triggered early (on imports, for example).
To make sure all DeprecationWarning messages are emitted we enable
them via the PYTHONWARNINGS environment variable.

Change-Id: I39f2ea6d46f353d346ab62e9c1709e51264647b4

commit_message:
Make reproduce.sh header more accurate

We run on more than ubuntu trusty now, try to reflect that information
and tell people where to determine exactly what distro to run on to
properly reproduce a job. Also update the package list to include
libssl-dev as it is now needed for cryptography things.

Change-Id: I635b133b1775a6a931f520404a5fa8a23514e60f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/23/392923/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Support domain-specific configuration management
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-22 16:54:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/65257c67b9237bf54c10855ba627ceffd10618d2', 'message': 'Support domain-specific configuration management

Provide support for the domain-specific configuration storage available
via the REST API.

Domain configs are JSON blobs and we have fine grained control on them
via the Identity API. This fine grained control is not useful in the
client perspective, though - we can manage everything like Python
dictionaries and use operations like "update" whenever we want to delete
a specific group or option. This approach is similar to what is done in
the federation mapping API to handle mapping rules.

Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte <rduartes@redhat.com>

Partially Implements: blueprint domain-config-ext

Change-Id: Ie6795b8633fed38c58b79250c11c9a045b7f95a4

via the Identity API. This fine grained control is not defined yet in the
client, though - for now, we can manage everything like Python dictionaries
and use operations like "update" whenever we want to delete a specific group
or option. This approach is similar to what is done in the federation mapping
API to handle mapping rules.

Functional tests are also included, this is useful to check if the new
feature works in an integration environment.

Co-Auhtored-By: Henry Nash <henryn@linux.vnet.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte <rduartes@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Support domain-specific configuration management

Provide support for the domain-specific configuration storage available
via the REST API.

Domain configs are JSON blobs and we have fine grained control on them
via the Identity API. This fine grained control is not defined yet in the
client, though - for now, we can manage everything like Python dictionaries
and use operations like "update" whenever we want to delete a specific group
or option. This approach is similar to what is done in the federation mapping
API to handle mapping rules.

Functional tests are also included, this is useful to check if the new
feature works in an integration environment.

Co-Auhtored-By: Henry Nash <henryn@linux.vnet.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Rodrigo Duarte <rduartes@redhat.com>

Closes-Bug: 1433306

Partially Implements: blueprint domain-config-ext

Change-Id: Ie6795b8633fed38c58b79250c11c9a045b7f95a4

commit_message:
conf: remove use_local from conductor

use_local was deprecated since 13.0 release - this patch
removes it completely.

This legacy mode was introduced to bridge a gap during
the transition to the conductor service.
It no longer represents a reasonable alternative for deployers.

Change-Id: Ibb9deeaab79044d8655229076df72cb809b93a55
Implements: bp centralize-config-options-ocata

commit_message:
Add ci-script for upgrade on baremetal

The parameters needed are both those to upgrade
from one version to another and for the
hardware environment under test.

NOTE: There is a push to remove ci-scripts from
tripleo-quickstart. This review may move
to another repo.

Change-Id: I99c854123122c0c0549cfd1842880c7177763512
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/09/391309/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # CI test that does an upgrade of a full oooq deployment on baremetal. # Use the major_upgrade flag to switch between major and minor upgrade # $HW_ENV_DIR is the directory where environment-specific files are kept. set -eux RELEASE=$1 DELOREAN_HASH=$2 MAJOR_UPGRADE=$3 PACEMAKER=$4 TARGET_VERSION=$5 HW_ENV_DIR=$6 NETWORK_ISOLATION=$7 CONFIG_FILE=$8 PLAYBOOK=$9 # (trown) This is so that we ensure separate ssh sockets for # concurrent jobs. Without this, two jobs running in parallel # would try to use the same undercloud-stack socket. socketdir=$(mktemp -d /tmp/sockXXXXXX) export ANSIBLE_SSH_CONTROL_PATH=$socketdir/%%h-%%r bash quickstart.sh \ --ansible-debug \ --extra-vars upgrade_delorean_hash=$DELOREAN_HASH \ --extra-vars deployment_type=baremetal \ --extra-vars major_upgrade=$MAJOR_UPGRADE \ --extra-vars enable_pacemaker=$PACEMAKER \ --extra-vars target_upgrade_version=$TARGET_VERSION \ --extra-vars step_upgrade_overcloud=true \ --extra-vars set_overcloud_workers=false \ --working-dir $WORKSPACE/ \ --no-clone \ --bootstrap \ --tags all \ --teardown all \ --requirements quickstart-extras-requirements.txt \ --config $WORKSPACE/$HW_ENV_DIR/network_configs/$NETWORK_ISOLATION/config_files/$CONFIG_FILE \ --extra-vars @$WORKSPACE/$HW_ENV_DIR/network_configs/$NETWORK_ISOLATION/env_settings.yml \ --playbook $PLAYBOOK \ --extra-vars undercloud_instackenv_template=$WORKSPACE/$HW_ENV_DIR/instackenv.json \ --extra-vars network_environment_file=$WORKSPACE/$HW_ENV_DIR/network_configs/$NETWORK_ISOLATION/${NETWORK_ISOLATION}.yml \ --extra-vars nic_configs_dir=$WORKSPACE/$HW_ENV_DIR/network_configs/$NETWORK_ISOLATION/nic_configs/ \ --release ${CI_ENV:+$CI_ENV/}$RELEASE${REL_TYPE:+-$REL_TYPE} \ $VIRTHOST

commit_message:
[Testing] Xenial systemd cgroup messaround

One of the theories about the Xenial CI slowdowns is around cgroups.
This patch tests a few things:

* Enables CPU accounting
* Sets the CPU shares for the user.slice (where Ansible runs) to the max

   ,  '    .

Change-Id: Ibbd0ed2e4080947d87306ad22b27a22664e02a7e

subject: dd missing memory.resident to NOVA_METERS
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-11-01 17:33:59.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/resources/alarm_base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/88aff6b3031324ecc39ff1ed4d102ce816645b92', 'message': 'dd missing memory.resident to NOVA_METERS

memory.resident is missing from NOVA_METERS list. This causes the
wrong metadata format for alarms on this meter if a heat stack
is used to create it. Basically, you will see the query in the
alarm generated by the heatstack will incorrect be set to
metadata.metering.stack instead of metadata.user_metadata.stack.

Closes-Bug: #1623680
(cherry picked from commit a408ccd1791ba758ddaa81d1e1f3be9250623bd0)
'}]
commit_message:
dd missing memory.resident to NOVA_METERS

memory.resident is missing from NOVA_METERS list. This causes the
wrong metadata format for alarms on this meter if a heat stack
is used to create it. Basically, you will see the query in the
alarm generated by the heatstack will incorrect be set to
metadata.metering.stack instead of metadata.user_metadata.stack.

Change-Id: Ic95f8c98c020627c6c5322c905cbf1c160d8445b
Closes-Bug: #1623680
(cherry picked from commit a408ccd1791ba758ddaa81d1e1f3be9250623bd0)

commit_message:
Introduction of a new DSL: Elemental

Change-Id: I5a949fbee3e6e3eec4f62d711d37ae9a0b32c44c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/12/323612/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/kolla/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ========== docker-dsl ========== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/kolla/+spec/docker-dsl Operators need near complete customization of Dockerfiles to run with specific plugins or meet other CI requirements. This customization should occur outside of the runtime Dockerfiles since those should be immutable. Problem description =================== The current build system lacks many features required by Operators. The most significant of these is a simple easy to use mechanism to plug in stuff into existing containers. To do that presently the raw Dockerfile.j2 must be modified. Use cases --------- #. Work with all supported distributions: CentOS, Debian, Fedora, Oracle Linux and Ubuntu #. Maintain all metadata relating to a container set in one file for Kolla #. customize list of binary packages installed #. customize list of from source binary packages installed #. customize list of from binary binary packages installed #. customize list of from source source packages installed #. customize list of gpg signing keys used for either DEB or RPM #. Work with yum repo RPM files from URI #. Work with yum repo RAW files #. Work with apt repo DEB files from URI #. Work with apt repo RAW files #. Work with yum packakes RPM files from URI #. Work with yum packages RAW files #. Work with apt packakes DEB files from URI #. Work with apt packages RAW files #. Work with pip packages from python mirrors #. Work with proxies #. Customize files within the container #. Programmatically control and manipulate the metadata instead of hand modify Proposed change =============== Introduction of a new DSL: Elemental. The DSL stores all metadata related to a container set. The DSL is minimalistic in nature. Its sole purpose is to describe the packages and files that should be placed inside a Dockerfile. This is not a project to rewrite the world. This project is about solving the various problems with our build system as they exist today, specifically the varying degrees of customization people have bolted onto build.py. We need nearly full customization, the definition of which is described in this specification. After the DSL is parsed by yaml.loads, it is merged with 1 user-provided override file called ``elemental-merge.yml`` in /etc/kolla. If that file is not present no merging will be done. A merge will add any keys from elemental_merge.yml to the global DSL keyspace. After the merging is complete, a file called ``elemental-override.yml`` in /etc/kolla is read. If that file is not present, no overriding will be done. An override replaces what was there previously in the key with what is in the override key (and all of its children). The ``elemental-override.yml`` file offers a mechanism to delete existing content from Kolla's shipped DSL. A tool called eparse.py parses the DSL and produces raw Dockerfiles. The build.py tool builds the raw Dockerfiles output by eparse. A third tool is developed which takes all of the CLI from build.py and includes both build.py and eparse.py to compose a complete build system. The processing involves: #. Read the DSL for each container set #. Read the /etc/elemental-merge.yml file #. Read the /etc/elemental-override.yml file #. Merge the DSLs that were originally individual files into one dictionary #. Any entries in /etc/elemental-merge.yml are merged directly in the dictionary #. Any top level keys in /etc/elemental-override.yml completely replace any keys in the existing parsed dictionary #. For each container in the DSL: #. If a repo section exists in the final merged and overridden DSL, repo files will be written. Repo files may be raw files stored on disk, or URI locations in which case the distro specific tools will be used to install it. #. If a gpg_keys section exists in the final merged and overridden DSL, gpg files will be written. Gpg files may be raw files stored on disk, or URI locations in which case the distro specific tools will be used to install it. If the gpg_key should be retrieved from a keyserver, the correct Dockerfile commands will be written to do that. #. If a all_packages section exists in the final merged and overridden DSL, package install Dockerfile syntax will be written. #. If a bin_packages section exists in the final merged and overridden DSL, package install Dockerfile syntax will be written if building from binary. #. If a src_packages section exists in the final merged and overridden DSL, package install Dockerfile syntax will be written if building from source. #. If a pip_packages section exists in the final merged and overridden DSL, package install Dockerfile syntax will be written if building from source. #. If a all_commands section exists in the final merged and overridden DSL, raw native docker commands will be placed in the Dockerfile. #. If a bin_commands section exists in the final merged and overridden DSL, raw native docker commands will be placed in the Dockerfile. #. If a src_commands section exists in the final merged and overridden DSL, raw native docker commands will be placed in the Dockerfile. #. An optimization step to de-layer can happen last or at any of these steps. Security impact --------------- There is no security impact. Performance Impact ------------------ The build times will increase less then 5 seconds. Alternatives ------------ Use include files for jinja2. I am not sure exactly how this would work for the 39 containers we have. I guess we could have a /etc/kolla/build/neutron-server-custom-repo and repeat that same pattern for the following list ['bin_commands', 'src_commands', all_commands', 'bin_packages', 'src_packages', 'all_packages', 'repos', 'gpg_keys'] for every container we have. The downside of this approach taken to an extreme is container_images * 8 files would need to be added for customization. Adding 312 files just for customization seems extremely untidy and will end up looking alot like a DSL, just spread out all over the filesystem. I also have concerns about programming errors during making jinja2 customizeable which apply similarly to this specification. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <stdake@cisco.com> Can optionally can list additional ids if they intend on doing substantial implementation work on this blueprint. Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: mitaka-2 Work Items ---------- Testing ======= Unit tests and our functional gate. Documentation Impact ==================== The documentation will need to change minimally. References ========== The DSL reference:: base: all_common_commands: - first command run on all distro variants from source or from binary - second command run on all distro variants from source or from binary - ... bin_common_commands: - first command run on all distro variants from binary - second command run on all distro variants from binary - ... src_common_commands: - first command run on all distro variants from source - second command run on all distro variants from source - ... root: the root location from the docker directory where this container should be built centos: parent: The parent image used to build this image - in this case centos:7 repos: - First CentOS repository - Second CentOS repository - ... gpg_keys: - First gpg key - Second gpg key - ... all_packages: - First package to be installed from RPM from binary or source - Second package to be installed from RPM from binary or source - ... bin_packages: - First package to be installed from RPM from binary - Second package to be installed from RPM from binary - ... src_packages: - First package to be installed from RPM from source - Second package to be installed from RPM from source - ... all_commands: - first command run on this distro variants from source or from binary - second command run on this distro variants from source or from binary - ... bin_commands: - first command run on this distro variant from binary - second command run on this distro variant from binary - ... src_commands: - first command run on this distro variant from source - second command run on this distro variant from source - ... debian: same structure as centos fedora: same structure as centos oracleinux: same structure as centos rhelosp: same structure as centos ubuntu: same structure as centos

commit_message:
Remove hard-coded host group

A previous commit added a hard-coded host group to
rabbitmq-install.yml, instead of using the variable rabbitmq_host_group.
This commit updates rabbitmq-install.yml to use rabbitmq_host_group
instead.

Change-Id: I4c4f8d0b903cc56ed025b7223b52d3205d9c9d37

Regardless of documentation covering the supported Operating

commit_message:
Add supported Operating System check

Regardless of documentation covering the supported Operating
Systems for a given release, there are still issues that arise
which turn out to relate to someone using an unsupported
OS.

This patch adds an early pre-requisite check for both an AIO
and a full deployment to hard stop the deployment if an
unsupported OS is detected on any host.

Related-Bug: 1638113
Change-Id: I6bc1a15e1283d496adb82a67989486f814e341c7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/77/392477/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pre_tasks: - name: Check for a supported Operating System assert: that: - ansible_distribution | lower == 'ubuntu' - ansible_distribution_release | lower == 'trusty' or ansible_distribution_release | lower == 'xenial' msg: "The only supported platforms for this release are Ubuntu 14.04 LTS (Trusty) and Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial)"

commit_message:
Include barbican role in integrated release

Add playbook, haproxy service configuration, variable definition,
and environment definition files required to deploy barbican as an
integrated role of openstack-ansible.
